Dear Bernardina Piratini, March 30, 1838.

Having only written what is seen above, to dispatch the Senhor to that place, I receive your letter of the 28th of the current month and another from the compadre with the same date: I am therefore pleased by the state of health of our children, yet tears came to my eyes at your brotherâ€™s condition.

God wills it so, we must respect His decrees. Last night, without expecting it, the appointment to again occupy the place I had left came into my hands: judge for yourself how much this incident must have troubled me! I have already pledged my friendship and services to the President and the Republic to be excused from such an office; nothing has been granted to me; however, I will still be obstinate until you tell me what I should do regarding this: for despite seeing my adversaries faltering, and the slanders they cast upon me disproved, nonetheless my repugnance is invincible.

For the mulatto, I will send everything you commission me, as well as what your father requests, whom you will comfort, to receive with resignation the blow that heaven prepares for him.

I will cherish that our children are not in danger, especially Bruto, whose loss would plunge me into despair: embraces to all, regards to your father, mother, and siblings, and receive the heart of Almeida.

Madam. Feliz Retiro.
